head.title: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Hypocrisy on Privacy

hedline.hl1: How Will a Damaged Clinton Lead the Nation?; Hypocrisy on Privacy

abstract.p: Scott A Sandage letter says Pres Clinton is hypocritical in demanding privacy rights for himself when he has eroded the privacy rights of many Americans by his policies (Sept 8 Anthony Lewis column)

block.p: Anthony Lewis (column, Sept. 8) asserts that the President is entitled to what Justice Louis Brandeis called ''the right to be let alone.'' Among President Clinton's many hypocrisies are these: he demands privacy rights for himself, and yet he signed the Defense of Marriage Act, and his ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy has resulted in record discharges of lesbian and gay members of the armed forces.

Anthony Lewis (column, Sept. 8) asserts that the President is entitled to what Justice Louis Brandeis called ''the right to be let alone.'' Among President Clinton's many hypocrisies are these: he demands privacy rights for himself, and yet he signed the Defense of Marriage Act, and his ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy has resulted in record discharges of lesbian and gay members of the armed forces.
The endorsement of privacy by the President and many Americans is heartening, but do they want it for everyone?
SCOTT A. SANDAGE New York, Sept. 9, 1998
